title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, ASX gains after Wall Street rally ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And more evidence that the world's second biggest economy is slowing down because of weaker demand at home and abroard. China is importing and exporting less. That is big news for Australia as China is our biggest trading partner. China's exports dropped 14.5 per cent over the year to July, while imports fell 12.4 per cent according to customs data. It was the biggest decline in exports since February 2020, when China's economy was thrust into a pandemic lock down. And iron ore exports fell 2 per cent in July because of pollution curbs on steel making, although they rose from the same time last year. Iron ore is Australia's biggest export earner and the lion's share of our iron ore shipments go to China. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's imports and exports fall

children.content: And more evidence that the world's second biggest economy is slowing down because of weaker demand at home and abroard.
China is importing and exporting less.
That is big news for Australia as China is our biggest trading partner.
China's exports dropped 14.5 per cent over the year to July, while imports fell 12.4 per cent according to customs data.
It was the biggest decline in exports since February 2020, when China's economy was thrust into a pandemic lock down.
And iron ore exports fell 2 per cent in July because of pollution curbs on steel making, although they rose from the same time last year.
Iron ore is Australia's biggest export earner and the lion's share of our iron ore shipments go to China.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More and more economic data is showing the pull back in consumer spending because of the high cost of living. The Bureau of Statistics says household spending rose 1.8 per cent from June last year based on customer transactions from financial institutions. ABS head of business indicators Ben Dorber says it was the smallest rise in household spending since February 2021. "Spending on discretionary goods and services was down for the third straight month, falling 0.7 per cent over the year, as households adjust to cost of living pressures. "Non-discretionary spending rose 4.2 per cent, however the growth rate has been slowing since January, when it reached 21.0 per cent." Spending on goods fell, while spending on services including child care, legal services and personal care rose. People spent more on staples like food, but less on non discretionary items like clothes and food.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending continues to slow

children.content: More and more economic data is showing the pull back in consumer spending because of the high cost of living.

props.alt: Bar graph showing household spending over past year

children.content: Consumer spending
(ABS)
The Bureau of Statistics says household spending rose 1.8 per cent from June last year based on customer transactions from financial institutions.
ABS head of business indicators Ben Dorber says it was the smallest rise in household spending since February 2021.
"Spending on discretionary goods and services was down for the third straight month, falling 0.7 per cent over the year, as households adjust to cost of living pressures.
"Non-discretionary spending rose 4.2 per cent, however the growth rate has been slowing since January, when it reached 21.0 per cent."
Spending on goods fell, while spending on services including child care, legal services and personal care rose.
People spent more on staples like food, but less on non discretionary items like clothes and food.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The West Australian government has announced it will overturn new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws, which were passed in 2021 after the destruction of sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara. The government will restore the original act from 1972 with "targeted, simple amendments" after an outcry from property owners over the new legislation. Under the new planned amendments, traditional owners will be able to appeal against development decisions under Section 18 of the 1972 act. Traditional owners were prohibited from appealing or talking publicly about Rio Tinto's plans to blow up the 46,000-year-old caves in 2020 under the old legislation. WA Premier Roger Cook says the new laws were too complicated and placed unnecessary burdens on property owners. "Today's announcement is about listening to the people of WA. "It' s about carefully considering the circumstances in front of us. "The Juukan Gorge tragedy was a global embarrassment for Australia, something needed to be done. "No-one can argue with that. "But our legislative response was wrong." Mr Cook rejected speculation that the WA government is repealing the laws to help get the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed. "I have not had any communication with the prime minister or any federal members in relation to these laws. "The only contact I have had with the federal government in relation to these laws is when I contacted the prime minister yesterday to announce that we would be going in this direction." The Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura Aboriginal Corporation, say they feel betrayed by the plans to repeal the new legislation. PKKP corporation chairman Terry Drage: "The previous heritage act, which predates Native Title, permitted the wanton destruction of  Juukan Gorge," he says. "While the new act is not perfect, it is better than what it replaced. “If the state government had listened to community feedback during the consultation phase, we  would not be in this mess." The PKKP has called on the federal government to proceed with national cultural heritage laws, as recommended by the parliamentary inquiry into the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves. Mr Cook has ruled out "revisiting" new cultural heritage laws. Here's more from my colleague Keane Bourke in Perth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: WA to repeal 2021 Aboriginal heritage laws

featuredLink.title: Live moment: 'The laws went too far': WA Premier announces repeal of controversial Aboriginal Cultural Heritage laws

children.content: The West Australian government has announced it will overturn new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws, which were passed in 2021 after the destruction of sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara.
The government will restore the original act from 1972 with "targeted, simple amendments" after an outcry from property owners over the new legislation.
Under the new planned amendments, traditional owners will be able to appeal against development decisions under Section 18 of the 1972 act.
Traditional owners were prohibited from appealing or talking publicly about Rio Tinto's plans to blow up the 46,000-year-old caves in 2020 under the old legislation.
WA Premier Roger Cook
says the new laws were too complicated and placed unnecessary burdens on property owners.
"Today's announcement is about listening to the people of WA.
"It' s about carefully considering the circumstances in front of us.
"The Juukan Gorge tragedy was a global embarrassment for Australia, something needed to be done.
"No-one can argue with that.
"But our legislative response was wrong."
Mr Cook rejected speculation that the WA government is repealing the laws to help get the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed.
"I have not had any communication with the prime minister or any federal members in relation to these laws.
"The only contact I have had with the federal government in relation to these laws is when I contacted the prime minister yesterday to announce that we would be going in this direction."
The Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura Aboriginal Corporation, say they feel betrayed by the plans to repeal the new legislation.
PKKP corporation chairman Terry Drage:
"The previous heritage act, which predates Native Title, permitted the wanton destruction of  Juukan Gorge," he says.
"While the new act is not perfect, it is better than what it replaced.
“If the state government had listened to community feedback during the consultation phase, we  would not be in this mess."
The PKKP has called on the federal government to proceed with national cultural heritage laws, as recommended by the parliamentary inquiry into the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves.
Mr Cook has ruled out "revisiting" new cultural heritage laws.
Here's more from my colleague Keane Bourke in Perth.
